So, the most important question is what
is Horde? And it's kind of a hard
question to answer. Even if I ask the
team that makes it, they might not all
give the same answer because Horde has
so many different things that it can do
for you and your team. So the thing that
most people use it for is it's a CI/CD
system. It'll build all your Unreal code
and it'll do it pretty good. Uh it also
has a build health system. It also has a
distributed build system. It also has
device management. It has automated test
exeutors and probably more things in the
future.
So the question is why should you use
Horde instead of whatever else you're
using right now? A lot of people use
Jenkins or Team City or whatever they've
used with other engines. Why should you
use Horde?
Uh really the biggest thing is it's made
for Unreal by Unreal. Um all of the
things in Horde are specifically made to
work basically out of the box with
Unreal. Uh and it supports all of the
things that you would expect from
Unreal.
It is also the produ it's in production
here at Epic. So we use it to build all
of these products you can see here. Uh
it's used for Unreal Engine, for
Fortnite, for Rocket League, for
Metahuman, for Fab, all of the stores.
Everything gets built in Horde. Um this
will support any project UE 5.0 or
later. You can get away with other

automation tool and build graph, but I
don't recommend it.
So, one of the biggest things I think
coming from a lot of other build systems
and coming to Horde is that Horde is
very Perforcecentric, which is very
important to a lot of game teams. Um,
Horde allows you to use more than one
Perforce server, which like makes it
easier for you as a company to have more
stability in your build system. Like if
one of your servers goes down, it'll
just choose a different one and continue
without any problems. Uh, it also
supports using multiple distinct
different servers. So like Epic has one
Perforce server that has Fortnite and
Unreal in it. And there's another
Perforce server that we have that has
psionic stuff, so Rocket League and
things like that. And it can you can
pull from both of those different
servers independently.
Um it also has a really neat system for
caching files and reusing workspaces. So
you don't have to worry about your
Perforce server getting polluted by a
bunch of workspaces made by built
machines uh across like a bunch of
different edges, for example. Uh it's
also has a lot of optimizations to
minimize the amount of information that
it requests because as we all know
Perforce is not the greatest tool ever
and it can be pretty slow. So we've
tried to minimize the amount of
information that we request from
Perforce in order to sync and get our
build machines ready.
So build health is important. Obviously
you all know this. That's why you're
here. How does Horde help you?
So, Horde has a lot of things that you

Horde really makes it easier for us to

It also has Slack integration. Uh Epic
is a completely remote company, so we do
a lot of our communication through Slack
and not through just like getting up and
talking to a person at a desk. This
makes it really easy as a build engineer
to help people find out why their build
is broken. A lot of times people will

I don't know why it doesn't work. Here,
I can point them to the Slack thread

when it's fixed and then you can run

Uh, so the automation that we have with

will allow you to assign yourself to the

will give you a small snippet of what it

culprit.
Um, in some cases, or I should say in a

logging for to point out what is the

hey, uh, I think that your change here

You can see at the bottom here, uh you

Horde will automatically close this
defect if your next run of that change
list or higher fixes that issue. If it
is not fixed, it will reopen the issue
and then tag that person and be like,
"Hey, that didn't work."
So, like I said, Horde has a lot of uh

it's not really important that like oh

So, UBA is something that I hope a lot

working in an office uh and you want to
make your compiles faster, you can set
up a instance in your office and you can
use UBA on all of your developer

developer machines.
With Horde specifically, we take

Linux and Wine as UBA agents to minimize
costs and
year over year our costs keep going down

it has really been one of the key uh
cost savers for Horde and for on uh
Epic.
Um just some other things like the UBA

they will use uh compression to send

egress and ingress costs you have from
transporting data and also it will use
um
it will use instances in the same AWS

to one and then have them distributed to
the rest of the UBA agents and then send
everything back. This is mostly just
like I said to minimize costs and
improve efficiency.

So, the question is, how do we manage
all of this? There's a lot of things

So, part of it is the way that Cord is
configured. There are three major
configurations that are used day-to-day.
um and they have different sharing with
the game team themselves. So the project
JSON is per project, the stream JSON is
per stream in the project and then the
build graph itself is in the project
themselves in that stream.
So the first important thing is the
project JSON. This is owned by the build
team. We're the only ones that do any
editing to this because this will impact
how much resourcing is used. So
basically when Fortnite is ready to make
a new release stream, they let us know.
We will go add it to the project JSON
and enable it in hoorde so that they can
start using it. What this does is it
also makes it so that people can't

because you'll run out of hard drive

Uh this is owned by the project

So one of the things we do with Horde is
we share machines across streams. Um
there are some upsides and downsides to
this. One of the upsides is it saves
hard drive space because the difference
between Fortnite 34 and 30 and Fortnite
3410 is pretty minimal. Most of the
files are the same. Um,
but as you go further and further away
from the root, it gets the the the
differences get bigger and sometimes
even though it shouldn't be that big,
Fortnite puts Darth Vader AI in Fortnite
and then all of a sudden there's like a
thousand extra files that don't exist
before.
So, um, one of the things it can do is
it can save hard drive space, but
sometimes that's not true. Sometimes it
can save startup and shutdown time if
you can have a machine that can run in
multiple different streams. You don't
have to turn off that machine and turn
on a different machine and wait for
that. Um, it also reduces the amount of
maintenance we need to do because there
just not as many machines. Not every
branch gets its own specific machine.
Um, so some of the cons like I said are
the startup time can also be increased.
If you're going from Fortnite 34 to
Fortnite 35, there's going to be a
significant amount of difference and
switching over to that stream can take a
really long time. Um, it's also a
problem sometimes if people uh start a
lot of jobs at the same time. It's easy
to over provision the machine the the
pool by just having too many people
starting jobs. Uh, and sometimes some of
them are more important than others and
they'll get their own pool.
